title: How to Choose a Lawnmower

steps.headline: Opt for a walk-behind mower if your yard is less than 0.5 acres (2,000 m).
steps.description:
Estimate the size of your yard, or get an exact measurement from your home’s schematics. If you have a smaller yard, then you don’t need to spend as much time and energy trimming the grass. You also don’t need to set aside a lot of storage space for this type of equipment. Walk-behind mowers come in both gas-powered and electric models. Gas models usually need to be revved with a cord, while electric equipment can be turned on with the push of a button. These lawnmowers come in both push and self-propelled varieties. Like the name describes, push mowers
Walk-behind mowers tend to cut in a length of 20 to 22 inches (51 to 56 cm).

steps.headline: Go with a walk-behind lawnmower if you're on a budget.
steps.description: Walk-behind lawnmowers are the most cost effective options available. Gas-powered mowers can range anywhere from $170 to over $1,000. Electric equipment tends to be in the $200-$400 range. Take your budget and yard size into consideration before choosing the special features you want.

steps.headline: Maintain a small yard with a gas-powered push mower.
steps.description: Choose a standard, gas-powered lawnmower if you aren’t looking for anything fancy. If you have a small yard, you can get a lot done with this kind of equipment. However, keep in mind that gas-powered mowers tend to be very noisy, and may hurt your ears with constant, long-term use. Try using earmuffs whenever you mow the lawn. Gas lawnmowers tend to range from $270 to $400, depending on the exact features.

steps.headline: Multitask by using a mower that mulches and trims.
steps.description: Look for mowers that have “two-function” in the product title—this means that the equipment bags the cut grass and adds a layer of mulch to the ground. If gardening and landscaping is a big aspect of your yard, then you might want to use a lawnmower with a mulching feature. You can also purchase a “three-function” mower, which trims tough patches of weeds as well. The price for a multi-functional mowers tend to range from $360 to around $900.

steps.headline: Choose an electric mower if you have a small, flat yard.
steps.description: If your yard is under 0.5 acres (2,000 m), you might be a great contender for an electric piece of equipment. If you have a flat yard with relatively short grass, an electric walk-behindmower might be a great option for you. You can operate hand-held electric mowers with the push of a button, but you’ll have to replace the battery whenever it runs down. Electric mowers are a lot quieter than gas-powered equipment.

steps.headline: Opt for self-propelled mower if your property is large or inclined.
steps.description: Save time and energy by using a walk-behind mower that moves forward on its own. You can choose between an electric or gas-powered model, though the prices tend to vary.

steps.headline: Tend larger yards with a riding mower.
steps.description: Look into a riding mower if your property is larger than 0.5 acres (2,000 m). If you don’t want to dedicate a large chunk of your day to mowing, then a riding lawnmower might be the best option. If you invest in this type of equipment, be sure to have shed or other storage area on hand. Certain tractor models can also work as lawnmowers. Riding mowers cut in larger lengths, ranging from 30 to 50 inches (76 to 127 cm).

steps.headline: Select a rear-engine riding mower if you’re on a budget.
steps.description: Check for riding mower equipment that has “rear-engine” in the label—this means that the mower is powered from the back. If you have a yard that’s between 0.5 to 1 acre (2,000 to 4,000 m), then this type of mower could be a great option. Choose this style of equipment if you’re looking for something that’s wider than a walk-behind mower. Most rear-engine riding mowers cost at least $1,000. Many of these mowers cut in 30 inches (76 cm) amounts, which is more convenient than a walk-behind mower.

steps.headline: Manage tricky terrain with a zero-turn-radius tractor.
steps.description: Scale slopes and bumps easily with a zero-turn-radius tractor, which turns very easily. Use this style of equipment at a slow, easy pace to manage any terrain difficulties. You can purchase these mowers in both gas-powered and electric varieties. Electric mowers tend to be more expensive than gas-powered mowers, and tend to cost at least $2,000. Gas-powered mowers a bit cheaper, and start at $360.Did you know? If you manage a larger piece of property (e.g., a farm), you might want to consider investing in a tow-behind mower.
